text: At 13, I was sheltered and naive. We were at the Jazz & Heritage festival in NOLA.  My step dad gave me a couple bucks and told me to go buy some sodas for all us. When I came back, my mom, step dad, and little brother were gone.  I wondered around for hours looking for them, worried I was in trouble.  At the end of the day, I found them.  Years later, when I wasn’t so naive, and I realized that they did it on purpose, so that they could smoke pot at the fest.  My brother was younger and they could easily hide it and the smell from him.  But they knew I would have seen.  My mom let this man leave her son and let him walk around alone.   They abandoned me so they could get high.  I was so scared I would’ve listened to any other adult and would’ve followed them and got in their car.  Like I said I was sheltered and knew nothing of a “bad world or bad people”.

context_meta.summary: A laptop computer recovered from the Las Vegas hotel room where Stephen Paddock launched the deadliest mass shooting in U.S. history was missing its hard drive, depriving investigators of a potential key source of information on why he killed and maimed so many people, ABC News has learned. Investigators digging into Paddock’s background also learned he purchased software designed to erase files from a hard drive, but without the hard drive to examine it is impossible to know if he ever used the software, one source said. The absence of substantial digital clues has left investigators struggling to piece together what triggered Paddock to kill 58 innocent concertgoers and injure more than 500 others on Oct. 1.

context_meta.title: U.S. black rights group warns travelers off American Airlines
context_meta.summary: The leading U.S. black civil rights group has urged black travelers not to fly with American Airlines after what it called a pattern of racially biased incidents reported by passengers. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) accused the airline of subjecting black passengers to "disrespectful, discriminatory or unsafe conditions" as part of a corporate culture of racial insensitivity. "Historically, the NAACP has issued travel advisories when conditions on the ground pose a substantial risk of harm to black Americans," the group said in a statement on Tuesday.

text: This one sounds like my Aunt Judy who was the terror of every family gathering. I was too young at the time to realize what was going on other than she was the only one who provided entertainment at these boring affairs. She could become very insulting with each glass of wine or whatever she was drinking. But usually what she said was the truth which no one wanted to hear. I think I was the only one who actually missed her when she passed. The best event was the food fight on Thanksgiving 1951. It was classic. She was babbling on at the dinner table [which seated 12] when suddenly someone had had enough [I think it was Aunt Esther] and lobbed a drumstick at her, hitting her alongside the head. From that point on it was total chaos and I was in seventh heaven. When it was over with, the dining room was a picture to behold. There was food stuck in places I didn’t think possible. It was the most fun I ever had with my family. Everyone left - Aunt Judy was first - feet first - she passed out as usual - and my poor mother and father had to clean up the mess. I helped but not very much - I wanted to enjoy the moment. No one spoke to one another for over a year. That was sad - at least for me. Oh, for the good old days."

context_meta.title: Las Vegas shooter's laptop missing its hard drive
context_meta.summary: A laptop computer recovered from the Las Vegas hotel room where Stephen Paddock launched the deadliest mass shooting in U.S. history was missing its hard drive, depriving investigators of a potential key source of information on why he killed and maimed so many people, ABC News has learned. Investigators digging into Paddock’s background also learned he purchased software designed to erase files from a hard drive, but without the hard drive to examine it is impossible to know if he ever used the software, one source said. The absence of substantial digital clues has left investigators struggling to piece together what triggered Paddock to kill 58 innocent concertgoers and injure more than 500 others on Oct. 1.

text: To all the "pro-life' zealots, I have a question which has never been answered honestly. There is a correct answer, an answer which makes the pro-birth crowd squirm. The question is: A fertility clinic catches fire, you run for the exit. As you're running you hear a child screaming from behind a door. You  find a five-year-old child crying for help. But in the room next to that one you spot a frozen container labeled "1000 Viable Human Embryos." You can only save one but not both before succumbing to smoke. Do you A) save the child, or B) save the thousand embryos? There is no "C." "C" means you all die. The pro-birth crowd  will never answer honestly, because we all instinctively understand the right answer is "A." A human child is worth more than a thousand embryos. Or ten thousand. Or a million. Because they are not the same, not morally, not ethically, not biologically. This question absolutely destroys their arguments, and their refusal to answer confirms that. No one actually believes an embryo is equivalent to a child unless they're lying to you.  Thanks to Patrick Tomlinson for sharing this with us.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Rescue dog uses his smile to help find a forever home
context_meta.summary: Though City of Waller Animal Shelter and Rescue in Waller, Texas won't open for another two-and-a-half weeks, one shelter pup is already swimming in adoption offers.  Cheech, a pup who entered the shelter on Thursday, has pulled in a ton of attention for the pet shelter thanks to the dog's massive, toothy grin, KSAT reports. Photos of the "smiling" rescue first appeared on the shelter's Facebook page on Thursday, and more were posted on Friday. Those photos have since been shared more than 5,800 times.  SEE ALSO: Get your fluffy cat snuggles without the cat The post was such a success that the shelter issued an update with background on their facility (it was started by a group of first responders), and a link to a pet adoption form for those looking to take Cheech home. Naturally, the applications rolled in. "Cheech has MANY applications turned in, however we have tons of great homeless pups available," an update to the the post reads. Per a later update, one prospective applicant even phoned the County Sheriff's Office in hopes of learning more about the dog, a practice the shelter advises against. They've even shared follow-up posts encouraging applicants to consider other rescue dogs staying with the shelter. Still, the Cheech updates keep coming: A new update from the shelter said that application reviews for Cheech began Monday. Good luck to the applicants – the competition sounds stiff. [H/T: KSAT 12] WATCH: Baby manatees take to the sky for rehabilitation

context_meta.summary: Though City of Waller Animal Shelter and Rescue in Waller, Texas won't open for another two-and-a-half weeks, one shelter pup is already swimming in adoption offers.  Cheech, a pup who entered the shelter on Thursday, has pulled in a ton of attention for the pet shelter thanks to the dog's massive, toothy grin, KSAT reports. Photos of the "smiling" rescue first appeared on the shelter's Facebook page on Thursday, and more were posted on Friday. Those photos have since been shared more than 5,800 times.  SEE ALSO: Get your fluffy cat snuggles without the cat The post was such a success that the shelter issued an update with background on their facility (it was started by a group of first responders), and a link to a pet adoption form for those looking to take Cheech home. Naturally, the applications rolled in. "Cheech has MANY applications turned in, however we have tons of great homeless pups available," an update to the the post reads. Per a later update, one prospective applicant even phoned the County Sheriff's Office in hopes of learning more about the dog, a practice the shelter advises against. They've even shared follow-up posts encouraging applicants to consider other rescue dogs staying with the shelter. Still, the Cheech updates keep coming: A new update from the shelter said that application reviews for Cheech began Monday. Good luck to the applicants – the competition sounds stiff. [H/T: KSAT 12] WATCH: Baby manatees take to the sky for rehabilitation

context_meta.title: U.S. black rights group warns travelers off American Airlines
context_meta.summary: The leading U.S. black civil rights group has urged black travelers not to fly with American Airlines after what it called a pattern of racially biased incidents reported by passengers. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) accused the airline of subjecting black passengers to "disrespectful, discriminatory or unsafe conditions" as part of a corporate culture of racial insensitivity. "Historically, the NAACP has issued travel advisories when conditions on the ground pose a substantial risk of harm to black Americans," the group said in a statement on Tuesday.

ripostes.text: I really miss having a dog.  Love 'em.  Miss my chocolate lab.. succumbed to sinus malignancy.  Had to put him down. He lay quietly on the floor of the vet office, head on my foot, as he always had it when sitting next to me. I was fine until he got that injection and then I felt the head suddenly become heavy on my foot and I knew "that's it, fella.... no more sickness, no more pain"... Vet let me stay in the room, alone with dog for "as long as it takes... come out when you are ready".  I appreciated that gesture.  I now have cats... INSIDE CATS... not allowed to go out... they have everything except grass.  Food, water, cat trees, baskets, scratch boxes.  This cutie.."cheech" will have me longing for a pooch again.  Happy days, Cheech.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Rescue dog uses his smile to help find a forever home
context_meta.summary: Though City of Waller Animal Shelter and Rescue in Waller, Texas won't open for another two-and-a-half weeks, one shelter pup is already swimming in adoption offers.  Cheech, a pup who entered the shelter on Thursday, has pulled in a ton of attention for the pet shelter thanks to the dog's massive, toothy grin, KSAT reports. Photos of the "smiling" rescue first appeared on the shelter's Facebook page on Thursday, and more were posted on Friday. Those photos have since been shared more than 5,800 times.  SEE ALSO: Get your fluffy cat snuggles without the cat The post was such a success that the shelter issued an update with background on their facility (it was started by a group of first responders), and a link to a pet adoption form for those looking to take Cheech home. Naturally, the applications rolled in. "Cheech has MANY applications turned in, however we have tons of great homeless pups available," an update to the the post reads. Per a later update, one prospective applicant even phoned the County Sheriff's Office in hopes of learning more about the dog, a practice the shelter advises against. They've even shared follow-up posts encouraging applicants to consider other rescue dogs staying with the shelter. Still, the Cheech updates keep coming: A new update from the shelter said that application reviews for Cheech began Monday. Good luck to the applicants – the competition sounds stiff. [H/T: KSAT 12] WATCH: Baby manatees take to the sky for rehabilitation

Per a later update, one prospective applicant even phoned the County Sheriff's Office in hopes of learning more about the dog, a practice the shelter advises against. They've even shared follow-up posts encouraging applicants to consider other rescue dogs staying with the shelter. text: If people knew how many fabulous dogs, cats an other animals there are in shelters and how many never make it out alive, they would be shocked. Tens of thousands of wonderful animals are killed every month in the US, running into millions annually. Animals in shelters are not bad, or defective or less somehow, they have just had a life with nor breaks. We got our Weimaraner from the Chicago pound ( he died May 24th), our Australian Cattle Dog from a rescue in Michigan (he died May 31st), and our Yellow Lab as a giveaway after being rescued from a bad situation. Even our cats are rescues. Please spay/neuter and please think about a shelter pet for your next family member. You won't regret it!

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Rescue dog uses his smile to help find a forever home
context_meta.summary: Though City of Waller Animal Shelter and Rescue in Waller, Texas won't open for another two-and-a-half weeks, one shelter pup is already swimming in adoption offers.  Cheech, a pup who entered the shelter on Thursday, has pulled in a ton of attention for the pet shelter thanks to the dog's massive, toothy grin, KSAT reports. Photos of the "smiling" rescue first appeared on the shelter's Facebook page on Thursday, and more were posted on Friday. Those photos have since been shared more than 5,800 times.  SEE ALSO: Get your fluffy cat snuggles without the cat The post was such a success that the shelter issued an update with background on their facility (it was started by a group of first responders), and a link to a pet adoption form for those looking to take Cheech home. Naturally, the applications rolled in. "Cheech has MANY applications turned in, however we have tons of great homeless pups available," an update to the the post reads. Per a later update, one prospective applicant even phoned the County Sheriff's Office in hopes of learning more about the dog, a practice the shelter advises against. They've even shared follow-up posts encouraging applicants to consider other rescue dogs staying with the shelter. Still, the Cheech updates keep coming: A new update from the shelter said that application reviews for Cheech began Monday. Good luck to the applicants – the competition sounds stiff. [H/T: KSAT 12] WATCH: Baby manatees take to the sky for rehabilitation

context_meta.summary: Reversing a lower court ruling, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said Jessica Jauch was denied "basic procedural due process" by Choctaw County and Sheriff Cloyd Halford in being held so long, ostensibly because the court was not in session. Jauch's innocence is now undisputed. "A procedure calling for extended pre-trial detention without any sort of hearing is alien to our law," Circuit Judge Thomas Reavley wrote for a 3-0 panel of the New Orleans-based appeals court.

text: That's how I got my dog at the Humane Society. I walked along the cages looking at the dogs and there was this one small dog smiling and wagging his tail. I told them I'll take him. He was two years old. He passed away this last spring. He was nearly 19 years old. He was a good boy and I will never forget his smile. His name was Jeeves.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Rescue dog uses his smile to help find a forever home
context_meta.summary: Though City of Waller Animal Shelter and Rescue in Waller, Texas won't open for another two-and-a-half weeks, one shelter pup is already swimming in adoption offers.  Cheech, a pup who entered the shelter on Thursday, has pulled in a ton of attention for the pet shelter thanks to the dog's massive, toothy grin, KSAT reports. Photos of the "smiling" rescue first appeared on the shelter's Facebook page on Thursday, and more were posted on Friday. Those photos have since been shared more than 5,800 times.  SEE ALSO: Get your fluffy cat snuggles without the cat The post was such a success that the shelter issued an update with background on their facility (it was started by a group of first responders), and a link to a pet adoption form for those looking to take Cheech home. Naturally, the applications rolled in. "Cheech has MANY applications turned in, however we have tons of great homeless pups available," an update to the the post reads. Per a later update, one prospective applicant even phoned the County Sheriff's Office in hopes of learning more about the dog, a practice the shelter advises against. They've even shared follow-up posts encouraging applicants to consider other rescue dogs staying with the shelter. Still, the Cheech updates keep coming: A new update from the shelter said that application reviews for Cheech began Monday. Good luck to the applicants – the competition sounds stiff. [H/T: KSAT 12] WATCH: Baby manatees take to the sky for rehabilitation

Photos of the "smiling" rescue first appeared on the shelter's Facebook page on Thursday, and more were posted on Friday. Those photos have since been shared more than 5,800 times.  SEE ALSO: Get your fluffy cat snuggles without the cat The post was such a success that the shelter issued an update with background on their facility (it was started by a group of first responders), and a link to a pet adoption form for those looking to take Cheech home. Naturally, the applications rolled in. "Cheech has MANY applications turned in, however we have tons of great homeless pups available," an update to the the post reads. Per a later update, one prospective applicant even phoned the County Sheriff's Office in hopes of learning more about the dog, a practice the shelter advises against. They've even shared follow-up posts encouraging applicants to consider other rescue dogs staying with the shelter. Still, the Cheech updates keep coming: A new update from the shelter said that application reviews for Cheech began Monday. Good luck to the applicants – the competition sounds stiff. text:
According to the article, she was INDICTED by the Grand Jury, called a TRUE BILL. At the very least, she should have been given a copy of the Indictment, which was the basis for the #1 the arrest and #2 the Committal Order to the jail. So she was NOT arrested or held for NO REASON and once the case was dismissed in January 2013, she should have been immediately released.

This is NOT a case of two different justice systems or a case of poor Police work or even a case of lack of money. It was poor administrative work and poor representation by her Court Appointed Attorney.

The TRUE BILL Indictment from a Grand Jury STILL requires an arraignment and then the setting of a Court Date, possibly even a prelim, depending on state. The County Sheriff was acting WITHIN the scope of the law, as it was written at the time. The Court Appointed Lawyer FAILED to push the issue and file motions for arraignment or for bond.
Or, if these motions were filed, they were DENIED based on the law at the time.

The real problem is that 94% of America has NO IDEA on how a Grand Jury really works, who it is composed of, rules of evidence, witness questioning/statements and how the 5th and 6th Amendments fit into it because the proceedings of a Grand Jury are Secret.

To make it simple, the Grand jury system is primarily used to determine if there is Enough Evidence to bring a case to trial. Here in the Commonwealth of Virginia the Grand Jury system is used for ALL Felony cases. In some cases in conjunction with a prelim and some cases where reducing the Felony charge to a Misdemeanor.

context_meta.title: Mississippi woman wrongly jailed for 96 days can sue county
context_meta.summary: Reversing a lower court ruling, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said Jessica Jauch was denied "basic procedural due process" by Choctaw County and Sheriff Cloyd Halford in being held so long, ostensibly because the court was not in session. Jauch's innocence is now undisputed. "A procedure calling for extended pre-trial detention without any sort of hearing is alien to our law," Circuit Judge Thomas Reavley wrote for a 3-0 panel of the New Orleans-based appeals court.

context_meta.title: Deputy caught on video stealing from dead man's home
context_meta.summary: A sheriff's deputy in Florida, who was caught on home surveillance video last month reportedly stealing from a recently deceased man, was arrested by authorities Thursday. Deputy Jason Cooke of the Palm Beach Sheriff's Office was charged with burglary and grand theft with a firearm, WPBF reported. He was released on house arrest after paying a $28,000 bond. Cooke is accused of robbing a house that belonged to Moe Rosoff, an 85-year-old man who had injured himself in a blackout during Hurricane Irma and later died, ABC 10 News reported. Rosoff's family reportedly had asked authorities Sept. 12 to do a welfare check on their father, who was braving the storm alone. Three deputies found the elderly

context_meta.title: Texas woman finds video of man raping her daughter in 'deleted photos' folder on tablet
context_meta.summary: San Antonio police said the woman was checking Gonzalez's tablet Sunday to see what games her children had been playing, KENS-TV reports. She opened a "deleted photos" folder and discovered video of Gonzalez raping the 7-year-old girl as well as nude pictures of her, according to an arrest report. The woman called police, who arrested Gonzalez later Sunday.

context_meta.title: A decorated Cleveland police officer-turned-fugitive takes his life after six-hour standoff
context_meta.summary: A SWAT team surrounded a house on the west side of Cleveland at 11 a.m. Tuesday. Inside was Tommie Griffin III, 52, a former police officer who once worked with several members of the SWAT team. Griffin had spent 22 years as a decorated member of the Cleveland Police Department, until he allegedly pistol-whipped and raped his girlfriend in January, which led to his arrest and subsequent resignation from the force. He'd spent the past several months under house arrest. Then on Saturday, he cut off his GPS ankle monitor, prompting a manhunt by the U.S. Marshals Service that eventually brought the SWAT team to the house in the Kamm's Corners neighborhood. context_meta.title: Judge denies teens bond in Michigan rock-throwing death
context_meta.summary: A judge on Tuesday denied bond to five Michigan teenagers who are charged with second-degree murder in a deadly rock-throwing incident on Interstate 75. All five suspects in the death of 32-year-old Ken White entered not-guilty pleas in a Genesee County court. White, a father-of-four from Mount Morris, was a passenger in a van when a six-pound rock thrown from an overpass smashed through the windshield, killing him, last week. Police say at least 20 rocks were found on the interstate, 80 miles north of Detroit. Other cars were damaged.  Mikadyn Payne (left), 16 and Trevor Gray (right), 15, are among five Michigan teenagers charged with second-degree murder, conspiracy and property destruction

context_meta.title: HIV-infected school aide accused of sexually victimizing 42 children in Maryland
context_meta.summary: A former Maryland school aide and track coach accused of sexually assaulting several male students while he was HIV positive was indicted Friday on more charges as the number of victims has nearly doubled. The Charles County State Attorney's Office announced Monday a 206-count indictment for Carlos Deangelo Bell, 30, a stark increase from the 119-count indictment handed out in late July. Bell is now accused of assaulting 42 juveniles after officials originally reported 24 victims in July. "The ages of the alleged victims at the time the offenses were committed range from 11 years old to 17 years old," the state attorney's office said. context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Celine Dion posts rare photo of her twins on their birthday
context_meta.summary: Oct. 24 (UPI) -- Celine Dion gave fans a rare glimpse of her twins on their birthday. The 49-year-old singer shared a picture with Eddy and Nelson, her younger sons with late husband Rene Angelil, from their Michael Jackson-themed birthday party Monday. "Can't believe you are already 7 years old... Time flies! Happy birthday, my loves!" she captioned the image. "I'm so proud of all of my boys! Mom xx... [photo by]: @denisetruscello." The snapshot shows Nelson and Eddy wearing black and white outfits inspired by Jackson, who died at age 50 in 2009. Several figurines of the late singer can be seen on a table in the background. Dion is also mom to 16-year-old Rene-Charles, her eldest son with Angelil.

The kids should have been taught not to talk to him, or open the door to speak, as someone could push their way in or pull them out. If he's waiting by house, go to a different, pre-arranged house. Talk to your parents and I would hope these parents get more involved then. Taking pictures of the home's layout and being aware of everyone's schedules is not a good thing.

Also, as soon as a child is mature and responsible enough, I would have them learn to handle a gun. A 13 yr old in SC had the training and ability and calmness to fend off armed home invaders that started shooting at him before his father could even get downstairs. He won, they lost, and he and his father survived.  The DC family that were all killed (father, mother, maid, and 12 yr old son) in the planned home invasion, might have lived had the family had guns. Instead, the twelve yr old was the focus of them torturing him, for days before the family was all murdered. 

The girl's brother was 12. At some point he could be entrusted to learn proper gun handling. It could mean life or death. Have emergency plans and practise them.
